video.title: Database Design Course - Learn how to design and plan a database for beginners
video.description:
This database design course will help you understand database concepts and give you a deeper grasp of database design. 

Database design is the organisation of data according to a database model. The designer determines what data must be stored and how the data elements interrelate. With this information, they can begin to fit the data to the database model.

Learn more about this course on Caleb Curry's website: https://www.calebcurry.com/freecodecamp-database-design-full-course/

⭐️ Contents ⭐
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:03:12) What is a Database?
⌨️ (0:11:04) What is a Relational Database?
⌨️ (0:23:42) RDBMS
⌨️ (0:37:32) Introduction to SQL
⌨️ (0:44:01) Naming Conventions
⌨️ (0:47:16) What is Database Design?
⌨️ (1:00:26) Data Integrity
⌨️ (1:13:28) Database Terms
⌨️ (1:28:28) More Database Terms
⌨️ (1:38:46) Atomic Values
⌨️ (1:44:25) Relationships
⌨️ (1:50:35) One-to-One Relationships
⌨️ (1:53:45) One-to-Many Relationships
⌨️ (1:57:50) Many-to-Many Relationships
⌨️ (2:02:24) Designing One-to-One Relationships
⌨️ (2:13:40) Designing One-to-Many Relationships
⌨️ (2:23:50) Parent Tables and Child Tables
⌨️ (2:30:42) Designing Many-to-Many Relationships
⌨️ (2:46:23) Summary of Relationships
⌨️ (2:54:42) Introduction to Keys
⌨️ (3:07:24) Primary Key Index
⌨️ (3:13:42) Look up Table
⌨️ (3:30:19) Superkey and Candidate Key
⌨️ (3:48:59) Primary Key and Alternate Key
⌨️ (3:56:34) Surrogate Key and Natural Key
⌨️ (4:03:43) Should I use Surrogate Keys or Natural Keys?
⌨️ (4:13:07) Foreign Key
⌨️ (4:25:15) NOT NULL Foreign Key
⌨️ (4:38:17) Foreign Key Constraints
⌨️ (4:49:50) Simple Key, Composite Key, Compound Key
⌨️ (5:01:54) Review and Key Points....HA GET IT? KEY points!
⌨️ (5:10:28) Introduction to Entity Relationship Modeling
⌨️ (5:17:34) Cardinality
⌨️ (5:24:41) Modality
⌨️ (5:35:14) Introduction to Database Normalization
⌨️ (5:39:48) 1NF (First Normal Form of Database Normalization)
⌨️ (5:46:34) 2NF (Second Normal Form of Database Normalization)
⌨️ (5:55:00) 3NF (Third Normal Form of Database Normalization)
⌨️ (6:01:12) Indexes (Clustered, Nonclustered, Composite Index)
⌨️ (6:14:36) Data Types

⌨️ (6:39:23) Inner Join
⌨️ (6:54:48) Inner Join on 3 Tables
⌨️ (7:07:41) Inner Join on 3 Tables (Example)
⌨️ (7:23:53) Introduction to Outer Joins
⌨️ (7:29:46) Right Outer Join
⌨️ (7:35:33) JOIN with NOT NULL Columns
⌨️ (7:42:40) Outer Join Across 3 Tables
⌨️ (7:48:24) Alias
⌨️ (7:52:13) Self Join

topLevelComment.author: Massimo
topLevelComment.text:
Pro tip: 
3rd normal form is very rarely used in production, it is infact to be avoided. Why?
- It's almost always useless to normalize lookup tables since they contain few data.
- It becomes unnecessarily complex to query data.
- database design must FIRST AND FOREMOST be done with the business case in mind. Does It make sense for the business to split product data into a hierarchy of related minuscule tables? No it does not.

Normalize when it is useful to do so, otherwise your project will resemble a school test .

topLevelComment.text: @2:11:20. I think a one-to-one relationship can ALWAYS be stored as entity and attributes instead of using two tables. topLevelComment.author: DJJonPattrsn22
topLevelComment.text:
Good job!  You keep the students attention by making us laugh.  Thank you!

The word "attribute" can be used as a noun (to represent a THING), or as a verb (to describe an action, something one DOES).   Each usage has a unique pronunciation.
When used as a verb, as in the sentence:  "I attribute the barking to my neighbor's dog." the stress falls on the 2nd syllable.   at-TRI-bute
When used as a noun, as in the sentence:  "Water has two extremely important attributes."  the stress falls on the 1st syllable.  AT-tri-bute
Stress is also sometimes referred to as emphasis or accent.  I am denoting stress with capital letters.   Here are some other examples:
re-LA-tion
EN-ti-ty
DA-ta-base
A-na-lyst
a-NA-ly-sis

My point…  You are using the WRONG pronunciation dude, and it seriously calls your credibility into question.  Sincerely!   If an instructor does know how to pronounce one of the most basic words that is fundamental to the topic, how in the world am I supposed to have confidence that he actually knows what he's talking about?

You are clearly using attribute as a noun, but you're using the pronunciation that indicates a verb.  Just look it up, you'll see!   These are not two alternate pronunciations that are interchangeable.  One it used to indicate noun usage, the other is for verb usage.  This isn't just a colloquial difference, this is true for every dialect of English.

topLevelComment.author: Yair Eshel Cahansky
topLevelComment.text: Theres another reason to use non capital letters for table name in mysql. The scema, and sometimes the data is stored in a file with this name. Windows file names are case insensitive, while linux filenames are case sensative. That means you'll find that things that worked on your local machine, don't work in production and vise versa. I had this bug once, and threw 3 work days on it, because this issue is so rare. Save yourself the troubles.

topLevelComment.author: vwesi H
topLevelComment.text: aws

This is definitely the place to start before taking a DB boot camp. 

I'm doing a Bootcamp class now and I probably would have been at a loss had I not watched this lecture, first. 

It's long, but that's bc  it's comprehensive. He really gives a good foundation of DB theory concepts, which is immensely helpful to have set in mind BEFORE you try to put it into practice. 

I like how he builds on concepts and repeats them as they apply to the new concepts he's introducing. This really helps set the basic framework into your mind. 

The repetition and incremental review is good.

topLevelComment.text:
@Caleb, great video, thanks for doing this!!
At this point in time (1:05:47), you're adding IDs to your user table, and somehow reached the conclusion that the two rows now relate to different entities, while a SSN would have promised that (because the Govt makes sure SSNs are unique) this arbitrarily assigned userID should not. I think this is called a surrogate key, and it's a somewhat artificial way to create uniqueness, but you still don't know if you have entity duplication or not...

topLevelComment.author: Angel
topLevelComment.text:
Great review of relational databases!
Though, if it's your first time learning relational databases and you don't know SQL syntax, know that this video doesn't cover SQL syntax, so you'll need to learn a bit more pausing the video from time to time looking up syntax examples.  Thankfully SQL syntax is quite minimal and is easy to look up using the terms in this video.
edit: He does cover some syntax when getting into joins at the end.

topLevelComment.author: Moco Coco
topLevelComment.text: Speaking with about 4 years of experience in programing including Microsoft SQL server I can say that as far as natural vs surrogate keys are concerned surrogate key is used without a second thought. Most DB servers have this built in Auto Increment feature with number (integer usually) seed and increment options to pick and then they auto increment without any necessary care from our side. In special cases a so called GUID is used (Global Unique Identifier) which is a 30 something (39 I think) characters in length which at least by the book should be unique in the entire world. But matching 39 characters against thousands or even millions of rows in a Child table takes a lot more resources and time.

topLevelComment.author: Valeriia Protsko
topLevelComment.text:
Great explanation, thanks! Spreadsheets and Database are both powerful ways to store the data, and I do not necessarily agree with the examples for Excel vs Database, it would be probably easy to select the employees in Excel then learn how to write a proper query. They are different in another way - when you enter data to the spreadsheet it is your responsibility to maintain order and put correct information into the right cell. If you intended to put data into cell B5 but entered it into C5, Excel wouldn't inform you about this. In relational databases, there is a structure that you have to obey. I recommend checking Airtable.com to build a prototype and practice with database design, understand the tables and records,  (they have a generous free plan).
_________added after watching all 8 hours (yay!! I did it)______
All the information is organized in a perfect way, and it makes total sense. If Caleb skipped the beginning or made it faster, it would be much harder to understand the normalization and joints. Totally worth watching. After this video, it will be easy to practice in real DB.

replies.author: Mr. Anderson
replies.text:
​@Andy Miller I wouldn't say specialize, the next step could be learning just enough php or any other server side language, anyways php is the easiest, just learn enought to make a database connection and process forms, then model something, just whatever. One good strategy could be to watch, and think how your local business work, model them, and start playing with that. If that seems just too much and you don't know where to start, try to make classic projects: todo list, sales system. All the above if you want to be a freelancer.

On the other sider if you are pursuing a serious career as a developer I'll add a couple of things: learn formally about entity relationship modelling, get a book on database modelling to learn concepts like cartesian product, sets theory, and at least the object oriented programming paradigm to make organized code. That surely could help!
